title: Tuesday, 15th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

But let's start with something un-Trumpian, but ugly nonetheless

PM

11:02 am
PM

So Waitrose has taken to running full blown ads on poison news thief site Mailonline

PM

Does that fit with the brand, do you think?

PM

There's a new-ish Waitrose near me in Greenwich

11:03 am
PM

It's full of middle class types and finance people

PM

Who queue respectfully for coffee

PM

And have young irritating kids

11:03 am
PM

It's not at all Daily Mail

PM

Really kind of weird that

PM

Just thought I'd share!

11:04 am
BE

Hm.

BE

If I remember my Media Studies O Level correctly, the Mail (print edition) had a larger AB1 readership than the Times.

PM

(Boncoeur:-- no zapper risk there at all)

11:05 am
BE

Not in terms of percentage of readership, to be clear, but in terms of reach.

PM

I know what you mean, but it's rather like saying that lots of people are quietly racist and most men like leering at women's bodies

PM

Therefore it's a great advertising platform

11:07 am
PM

I just think it's awkward for Waitrose. Really awkward

BE

....................... Um, I'd not disagree with that statement.

PM

Who's the chairman of John Lewis now?

11:08 am
BE

No idea.

PM

Sir Andrew Charles 'Charlie' Mayfield, it seems

PM

Does Sir Andrew class himself as a Mailonline leerer?

11:08 am
PM

Does he think his customers are such?

BE

I imagine they gave their ad account to Karat or whoever and paid for x number of placements and x level of reach. I doubt he goes though the list of site placements personally.

PM

Yeah, exactly

11:09 am
BE

And more generally, I'm made a little uncomfortable by his concept that that advertisers are responsible for the editorial in the newspapers they advertise in, as best represented by the recent Lego fuss.

BE

The separation of editorial and advertising departments has, historically, been seen as quite important for the media.

BE

But it goes both ways.

11:11 am
BE

Should ad placement people try to dictate editorial with money? I'm not sure. Isn't that why Oborne resigned?

PM

Yeah, important from our side. But your band has to align with the content. Otherwise, mens fashion would advertise on porn site

PM

s

11:12 am
BE

It's the Mail, not a "porn site" ... I think that might be a straw man bog enough to entrap Edward Woodward.

BE

Anyway, let's push on to what we're paid to do.

PM

Guess so

11:12 am
undefined
PM

Trump trade over, apparently

PM

Sea of blue in bond markets

11:13 am
PM

Dollar dips

PM

Tho not against un-mighty sterling

PM

So the Footsie is up

11:13 am
PM

Go figure all this

BE

Yeah, kinda. Starting from the top, in terms of FI, it looks like a bit of a retracement after a pretty incredible rally.

BE

The reflationary trade and the rotation and all that stuff we've been talking about for a week, in between predicting a new dark ages.

11:14 am
BE

Want Citi? Have Citi.

PM

Sure

BE

We remain bearish, but not that bearish from current levels in core rates, with for instance our 10yr Bund target at 0.50%.

How far the market sell’s off depends on the economic momentum induced by the Trump stimulus and how far his reforms induce a productivity recovery. As we have noted, deficits and reform, are factors that push neutral rates higher (r*).

From here, probably the most bearish outcome for rates is a Fed rate pass at the December meeting. Markets will fear more inflation and hotter growth.

We continue to watch the USD FX as a key limiting factor for the sell-off. Strength in the USD, allied to higher rates, squeezes global liquidity and where Trump adds to global nominal GDP, the EM complex can take away.

11:15 am
BE

Quick summary of our thinking

The Republican clean sweep is outright bearish rates. It is myopic to see trade wars as bond market friendly because savings outflows lift real rates. Meanwhile, inflation expectations have to rise on autarky, just like Brexit.

The fiscal stimulus is the upfront focus. This lifts global nominal GDP. More importantly, fiscal deficits allied to deregulation & reform, also lifts neutral rates (r*).

This tempers secular stagnation themes and gives bear steepeners as markets price higher equilibrium yields. The global spillover works as a positive growth shock though policymakers will want confirmation before expressing confidence. For € rates, ECB taper risk would be enhanced on a firmer USD which means little relief for periphery, but a materially stronger USD sows the seeds of EM led growth weakness & bonds to reverse.

How far can bond sell-off? We have 0.5% on Bunds and see weakness in Treasuries too but global flows support the 10yr Treasury stabilizing at 2.35% in Q1-17 and nearer 2.5% in H2-20171.

BE

(@Flaneur: that's not what he said.)

PM

(What did he say?)

11:17 am
BE

(He said: "Excessive focus on monetary policy is a massive blame deflection exercise".)

PM

( Flaneur:, you need to be less angry. I've got over my depression. Positive thinking!)

PM

(Isn't that kinda what Flaneur said?)

11:18 am
PM

(And yeah, i know we are being distracted)

BE

(But he didn't say it apropos of "blaming the BoE for low rates" .... That's a misrepresentation.)

PM

(Ok, im not going to argue)

11:20 am
BE

("It’s very important to distinguish between the stance of monetary policy and the reasons why global interest rates are low, the reasons why inequality has increased across major economics.

Those are caused by much more fundamental factors. And an excessive focus on monetary policy in many respects is a massive blame deflection exercise.")

PM

(fair enough)

BE

(Yep. That's the full quote. And it seems fair enough to me, because it's right.)

11:21 am
undefined
PM

Loads of results

PM

Inflation down shocker

11:21 am
PM

Actually, I have an important quote to share on that

PM

Good morning,

Following the BoE announcement on the decline in inflation rate I thought you might be interested in a comment from Calum Bennie, savings expert at Scottish Friendly, who describes the fall as a pause for breath. Do let me know if you have any questions or require further information.

Best

PM

Calum Bennie, savings expert at Scottish Friendly, said: “The surprise fall in inflation for October to 0.9 is just a pause for breath."

11:22 am
PM

thumbs up

BE

"Scottish Friendly" is an oxymoron.

PM

Too right

11:22 am
BE

Have RBC too. Because Canadian Friendly isn't.

BE

In October CPI inflation actually fell to 0.9% y/y from 1.0% y/y last month against expectations. The market consensus, the BoE and our own forecast were for a rise to 1.1% y/y. There was a similar surprise with RPI inflation where the rate held at 2.0% y/y against an expected rise to 2.3% y/y. The moderation in core inflation from 1.5% y/y to 1.2% y/y was behind the surprise in CPI.

More specifically, the clothing and footwear component was the single biggest factor explaining the drop back in the annual rate of CPI inflation between September and October where prices barely changed this year but were up over 2% between the same two months last year. The easing in headline inflation was however also partly due to university tuition fees and prices in the ‘recreation and culture’ sector.

Set against that fuel prices made a clear positive contribution with the ONS noting “part of the increase in oil prices in 2016 can be explained by depreciation of sterling against the US dollar”. Note also that whilst CPI inflation fell back, for producer price inflation (PPI) on the input side, there was an increase to 12.2% y/y from 7.3% y/y. The breakdown of that index is revealing from the perspective of the exchange rate pass-through theme. For example, “other home produced materials” are still in deflation territory at -0.5% y/y but imported components are registering double-digit inflation with “imported metals” up 25.6% y/y for instance.

The pass-through theme is in its infancy as far as CPI inflation is concerned, but it is difficult to argue it isn’t on the way when one looks as those PPI figures. Despite a downside surprise today this doesn’t trigger a change of view on the outlook for us. It is still likely that CPI inflation could overshoot the 2% target at some point in H1 2017. In that sense the November Inflation Report policy conclusion of the MPC to sit in neutral for a while still appears valid.

As CPI inflation has dipped back to being more than one percentage point below the 2% target an exchange of open letters between the Governor and the Chancellor will be required. These will be published alongside the minutes of the next MPC meeting on 15 December.

BE

Anyway, sterling down again.

11:23 am
BE

(@J: embargoed to media until midday I think. I could tell you what was in it, but someone in a better suit than mine would shout at me.)

The easing in headline inflation was however also partly due to university tuition fees??? Since they are pegged at 9k for now, that must mess with the figs

11:25 am

sure

BE

In this month’s November Inflation Report, the Bank of England forecast that UK CPI
inflation would accelerate to 2.7% in 2017 and would stay above 2.5% through 2018
and 2019. However, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) has
forecast that CPI inflation will rise to 4% next year.
The current consensus forecast is that CPI inflation will average 2.5% in calendar year
2017 but with a massive distribution from a high of 3.5% to a low of 1.9%. On balance,
the consensus forecast for CPI inflation still looks too weak given the price pressures
already emerging from sterling’s depreciation.
UK consumer spending grew by 3.9% in nominal terms in the year to Q2 2016.
However, just 1.0 percentage point reflected price rises, so that real spending rose by
2.9%. Looking forward, price pressures look set to eat into real incomes and spending to
a far greater degree. For example, average weekly earnings grew by 2.0% in the year to
August and are not expected to pick up with jobs growth now slowing post-Brexit.

BE

Oh, and while we're here .... This caught my eye. From Natixis.

11:25 am
PM

Patrick Artus?

BE

Yep. Who I like. He always writes like he's sending telegrams from the edge of the abyss.

BE

If we calculate "mechanically", we find that UK
inflation in 2017 is likely to be very high, which means
that a recession is certain in the United Kingdom if
this inflation (4%) materialises

11:26 am
BE

In 2017, UK inflation will be driven up by:


The rise in the oil price;
The rise in import prices caused by the depreciation of the pound
sterling.
When we forecast UK inflation in 2017 by using the usual methods, we
find a very high level of inflation (at least 4% per year), which would
lead to a decline in household demand and to a recession.

PM

( FATDAZ -- i have the flash FMS post US election from a few days ago, but nothing today as yet.)

So the working here is that wage inflation in the United Kingdom will be 2.3% in 2017.

11:27 am

11:28 am

"The automatic effect of the rise in import prices on inflation is around 4.2 percentage points."

PM

BE

If UK inflation actually reaches 4% or more in 2017, by accumulating the effect of labour
costs, of the oil price and of the exchange rate, the loss of real income and consumption is
likely to be very significant

11:29 am
BE

BE

So, yeah. Either there's some pain to come in import-export margins or we're headed into recession. That's his thesis.

11:33 am
BE

Today, we get all of these.

BE

Numbers are fine, guidance is a wee bit weak, India written down a bit but no one really cares.

BE

Jefferies incoming. They're buyers.

11:35 am
BE

VOD reports 2Q16/17 service rev growth 50bp above consensus with 1H EBITDA
1.1% ahead. Germany/Italy notably strong. FY EBITDA guidance narrowed as
expected given the competitive overhang in India. Beyond this, 2H rev guidance
looks a bit more conservative than previously but confidence in cost-cutting
prospects looks reinforced given mgmt. commentary about "refreshed" Fit for
Growth and new internal 3-year margin targets.

BE

Headlines. Group service revs +2.4% y/y (cons +1.9%; 1Q 2.2%), ahead of high-1's
guidance. Indian growth slowed by less than expected although VOD is stressing that
competition increased towards the end of the quarter with voice promos (from Aug) and
lower volume top-ups (attributed to customers making use of Jio's promotion). Service
rev growth in Europe was ahead: +1.0% y/y (cons +0.4%, 1Q +0.3%) with Ger/IT beating
by 120bp/90bp. AMAP +7.1% y/y (cons +6.3%, 1Q 7.7%) with India growth slowing only
100bp seq (40bp better than expected) but Vodacom/Turkey coming in 40bp/60bp light.
For 1H16/17, total revs €27,054m (-0.7% vs cons); EBITDA €7,906m (+1.1% vs cons). On a clean organic basis, Group EBITDA growth +4.3% y/y in 1H16/17 (vs +3.6% 2H15/16; +1.9% 1H). 1H16/17 FCF of €15m was dragging by the Spring capital creditor outflow as expected, still coming ahead of JEFe €(256)m.

BE

Guidance. Service rev growth is no longer expected to strengthen in 2H16/17. 3Q may
experience more pressure from the more competitive situation in India (how much will
depend on Jio's commercial tactics once its current 90-day promo expires at end-Dec)
partly offset by less carrier drag. Then 4Q growth faces an aggregate -100bp drag from
lapping last year's leap year boost (-40bp), German/NL accounting changes (-30bp) and
a likely German MTR drag (could be -30bp). Assuming a steady-state in Europe, group
service revs could develop from +2.3% in 1H to low-2's in 3Q and 1.0-1.5% in 4Q. As
expected the FY16/17 EBITDA guidance range is narrowed with the top-end trimmed:
now €15.7-16.1bn (previously €15.7-16.2bn). Guidance excludes one-off FX losses on FX-
denominated liabilities in Egypt following devaluation of EGP (impact estimated at €80m,
non-cash). With India more competitive, VOD believes the high-end is a stretch even with
Europe performing strongly. In the results release, VOD states that a recent benchmarking
analysis of its cost structure indicated continued scope for future savings. It says that "the Fit
for Growth programme has subsequently been refreshed and new internal 3-year margin targets have been set across the Group". FY16/17 FCF guidance of at least €4.0bn (before spectrum/restructuring) is reiterated (cons €4.2bn; JEFe €4.1bn).

11:36 am
undefined

Otherwise in telecoms, we have the quarterly rubbish statement from TalkTalk.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 189.70, down 11.4 (-5.67%), High: 207.00, Low: 182.70, Volume: 2.75m

11:38 am

11:39 am

11:40 am
BE

The problem this time around is that not many are signing up ......

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley with the detail on the KPIs.

BE

The quarter was dominated by the introduction of
the new simplified price plans. This meant TalkTalk scored well on customer
retention, but gross additions were less good. (1) Broadband net adds slowed: -
20k vs MSe -8k. Q1 was -9k; (2) Mobile net adds were stable: +46k vs MSe +50k.
Q1 was +48k; (3) Fibre net adds were good: +40k vs MSe +30k. Q1 was +36k; (4)
TV net adds declined further: -33k vs MSe -15k. Q1 was -23k; (5) Churn (monthly):
1.43% vs MSe 1.40%. Q1 was 1.36%. Looking ahead, management believes they can
stabilise the broadband base (with more emphasis on retail vs wholesale) in the
near term and eventually return to growth. Likewise, in TV, the company is
optimistic that positive customer additions are not too far away (YouView box
refresh).

11:41 am
BE

H1 step in EBITDA due to SAC reduction: H1 SAC & Marketing costs declined
from £152mn to £94mn in H1 2017. c30% of the improvement was due to lower
cost per customer addition from growth in digital sales and new Next Best Action
functionality for recommending services to customers. H2 will inevitably see
higher volumes (so higher variable costs), but management believes that online
optimisation benefits will continue to deliver lower cost per add.
Mobile and fibre in York update: In mobile, management acknowledge that the
transition to the O2 network is taking longer than initially expected, but it is
important to get the correct billing systems in place. For the fibre rollout in York,
TalkTalk has a build cost per home of £417, in line with their target of less than £500.
However, more cautious commentary on the EBITDA outlook: The company now
says that they expect to be at the low end of the £320-360mn FY17 EBITDA
range (Cons £320mn, MSe £354mn). The company ascribes this to the success of
re-contracting customers onto their new tariff plans. TalkTalk reiterated their
previous dividend message of at least in line with that of FY16.

BE

I've argued in the past, I'm sure, that copper-wire internet provision is a terrible business. All provide the same service using the same stuff, pretty much, and you only notice it when it doesn't work.

PM

(muppet central fair enough. Not my experience tho.)

(@Mouselet: Morgan Stanley upgrade of Hikma. We'll come to it.)

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 214.30, up 8.45 (+4.10%), High: 214.70, Low: 206.60, Volume: 11.51m
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 244.10, up 7.6 (+3.21%), High: 245.00, Low: 239.80, Volume: 4.20m
11:45 am
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 223.10, up 10.5 (+4.94%), High: 223.30, Low: 213.80, Volume: 9.75m

BE

Tesco sales up 3.6%, strongest growth since July 2013.

11:46 am

PM

BE

Also, the current round of Tesco store rejigs look quite nice. Passed one in ..... Ealing Broadway, was it? ..... at the weekend. They've gone for wood laminates and a restrained, grey-blue-silver colour scheme.

11:48 am
BE

It's much less shouty.

PM

thumbs up

BE

Anyway, this is the "first time Tesco has gained more market share than Aldi and Lidl combined (44bps) since October 2011" says Barclays.

11:48 am
BE

Who also say:

BE

Tesco’s branded sales saw an increase but most of its share gains were made through its private label products, both at the entry and premium levels. Tesco’s ‘Finest’ range has grown by 6% in the past 12 weeks, notably in crisps, fresh meat and chilled convenience – this will be important if Tesco is to deliver its margin target of 3.5-4.0% by ‘maxing the mix’. Kantar Worldpanel reports that much of Tesco’s growth has come from more affluent shoppers returning to the store, and average spend per trip is up by 2.1% to £20.69.

· ASDA’s recent weak performance has ameliorated – although sales are still down 3.9% - with stronger sales in its own-label lines this period.

BE

· Sainsbury (sales down -0.9%) and Morrison (sales down -1.3%) are broadly as we would have expected.

· The industry remains in deflationary territory, but over the last 12 weeks food deflation has fallen to -0.5%, from -0.8% last time. This is the lowest rate of deflation since October 2014 and the second month in a row that we have seen a 30bps sequential move – indicating a rapid rate of change. This is the 28th consecutive period of grocery price deflation. Deflation particularly impacted major categories such as poultry, bacon, sausages and detergents.

· Bearing in mind the food inflation data is a 12-week average, the chances are that deflation might be close to zero as we speak. This suggests that FX is indeed pushing the industry out of deflation.

· From an industry perspective, growth was +0.5% compared with +0.1% last month – on a 12-week rolling view, growth decreased slightly to +0.4% from +0.5% previously.

· Combining Aldi and Lidl, their growth slowed to ‘merely’ 6.4% with 44bps of share gains. This is their lowest growth rate on both measures for many years – you have to look back to December 2010 to find lower growth on a 12-week basis.

· The difference in growth rates between Tesco and the discounters has fallen to 6.2ppts, the lowest gap since late 2010 (see Figure 2 below). Over the most recent four weeks the gap is down to just 2.8ppts.

· Looking at the other retailers, Iceland has continued to deliver strong growth (+12.9%), but Waitrose has recorded a second month of just 0.3% growth.

11:49 am
BE

And Goldman, for a bit of grumbling.

BE

For the listed grocers this can be seen as a broadly positively release.
Deflation eased slightly, market growth accelerated and the discounters
continue to take sequentially less market share. We therefore expect a
broadly positive reaction to this print. However, we would note that most
of the growth improvement is coming from a base effect, with little
sequential change on a 2-year basis. We would also note that volume
growth appears to be slowing slightly.

undefined

PM

PM

But because we messed around talking about Waitrose and the poisonous Mailonline

11:51 am
PM

Melrose Industries still going up?

Melrose Industries PLC (MRO:LSE): Last: 172.13, up 4.13 (+2.46%), High: 179.00, Low: 169.50, Volume: 2.46m
BE

Because it's not indexed I keep forgetting to look.

11:51 am
PM

Trading statement here: http://www.investe...1611150700081521P/

PM

Redburn like em, still

PM

The fear before today was that Melrose would take the opportunity of a trading update to kitchen sink numbers, ‘as per normal’ for an acquisition. This is slightly unfair as FKI was purchased shortly before Lehman's went under, and Elster was acquired in the midst of a sharp European industrial slowdown in the summer of 2012. Melrose may have laser vision on cost bases but they don’t have a crystal ball for macro demand. This time around the industry backdrop has been more forgiving. Nortek has had a great start in the two months under Melrose's ownership.

11:52 am
BE

That's Stephen Swanton. Excellent analyst. Proper.

BE

Pity it's such a grind to get hold of his work.

PM

Here's some more then

11:53 am
BE

thumbs up

PM

There is not much in Melrose’s trading update but the comment that trading at “Nortek has been encouraging with many actions being taken in a short space of time” is fairly enlightening. The upshot is that consensus for FY17 will move closer to our forecast of £276m of operating profit (potentially up to a 5% upgrade for consensus).

Amongst the comments it is work on the AVC unit (audio/video equipment) that stands at the most. AVC was heavily loss making in previous years but Melrose already seem to have turned this around as we show below. Corporate costs, which had been running at 1.6-1.7% of group sales have already been cut with the company HQ closed and autonomy is in the process of being given back to the individual businesses.

Within the mix of businesses, we believe Air Quality is finding trading difficult despite the benefit of new products and industry shipments for kitchen range hoods being up 5% YoY in Q3. HVAC is also not performing quite as well as some of the peers (who were doing 6-7% growth in Q3). Security and Ergonomics are doing well and AVC has been improved as outlined above.

Overall, this is a positive update from Melrose. Tougher times will lie ahead as all the changes are put through Nortek and Brush is clearly finding life difficult. However, we do not envisage out top-of the range estimates changing

BE

Hm.

11:54 am
PM

So the sackings are going to plan, but trading is tough

undefined
BE

Hikma mentioned on the right earlier. That's Morgan Stanley pushing.

11:54 am
Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 1,747, up 123 (+7.57%), High: 1,747, Low: 1,658, Volume: 397.00k
BE

Big -- as in, 60 pages -- note about US generics.

BE

Conclusion is that Hikma's got a lot going on.

11:55 am
PM

7% -- quite a move!

BE

... which says to me that investors are happy to take Morgan Stanley sellside's word for the quality of Hikma's pipeline rather than doing any actual work themselves. Which ,speaking very generally, is the kind of thing that's caused some issues in the past. Nevertheless ....

BE

Note incoming.

11:57 am
BE

Our new deep dive into
Hikma's medium term pipeline and long term opportunities gives us increased
confidence. While it doesn't change the near term trajectory, it points to a
pathway for sustained growth and should lead to a multiple re-rating.

BE

Bottom up: our estimate of a $600m generic pipeline brings clarity. We have
uncovered what we believe to be 70% of Hikma's filed pipeline. Clarity on the
nature and timing of projects removes a key overhang. Hikma's acquisition of
Roxane was not only for its pipeline, but also its legal and R&D expertise, which
helps position Hikma to deliver and enter a higher value add market.

BE

Top down: significant opportunities remain in the broader market for Hikma.
We worked our way down from the 800+ drug list of pending generic filings and
found that Hikma is well placed to capitalise long term. A third of this list are
Central Nervous System drugs, an area the company has expertise in. We
estimate a further combined value of $750m comes from scheduled and
extended release drugs, two areas Hikma has been explicit in targeting. While we
do not know if Hikma is behind these specific filings, these areas represent the
generic opportunity set where Hikma is well placed and likely to pursue,
providing a healthy LT pipeline.

11:57 am
BE

Valuation attractive: in-line with EU Pharma does not reflect LT growth
prospects. With Hikma trading at 15x 2017e earnings, a substantial discount to
history, we see limited downside near-term. The stock has underperformed by
19% over the past 3 months; we see upside as we view the stock as oversold (DoJ
investigation (see here), sector de-rating) and believe the CMD Nov 15th could
bring incremental upside with visibility. Hikma's 17% earnings growth CAGR (17-
19e) supports our belief that Hikma deserves to trade at a premium.

BE

That DoJ investigation remains something to keep in mind, tho.

undefined
11:59 am
BE

Otherwise, we had perhaps the world's least interesting M&A scoop overnight .....

BE

By which I don't mean "we" ... I mean Brloomberg.

BE

By Ruth David, Dinesh Nair and Manuel Baigorri
(Bloomberg) -- Reynolds American Inc., the second-largest
cigarette seller in the U.S., is seeking a higher price from
British American Tobacco Plc after rejecting a $47 billion
buyout offer as too low, according to people familiar with the
matter.

12:00 pm

Here's RBC's.

12:03 pm
BE

According to Bloomberg and people familiar with the matter, Reynolds American has rejected the initial offer from British American Tobacco as the company is asking for a higher price. At current price and exchange rate, we estimate the offer values each share of Reynolds at $53.2, roughly in line with Reynolds' share price.

This is playing out as we expected. We’ve always regarded the first offer as the initial step in the negotiation process and believe BAT will need to increase the offer price

In our note "Camel’s back" published in October we estimate a fair value for Reynolds at $59 per share, meaning that the proposed acquisition is about value neutral. And also looking at different sensitivities on EPS, ROIC and Net Debt/ EBITDA for different levels of price paid and synergies, and we reach a similar conclusion. The deal just about works financially… but no more than that.

Our negative view on the stock is predicated on a moderation of margin growth coming from negative brand mix and moderation of cost savings from a level that we believe is not sustainable… and this value-neutral acquisition doesn’t really change our view. On top of this, we believe expectations for higher bond yields will continue to be a drag for bond proxies, negatively impacting tobacco names in particular.

BE

And here's Barclays'.

BE

Bloomberg reports overnight suggest that Reynolds has rejected BAT's $47bn offer for the group. Although not yet confirmed (there is no official statement from the companies), this is unlikely to be a surprise to the market as BAT was unlikely to be successful at the first time of asking. However, we note that with no competing bidders likely to emerge due to BAT's existing 42% stake as we discussed in our recent report “From cohabitation to marriage?, 21 Oct 2016”, the likelihood of BAT needing to substantially raise its offer is limited. Encouragingly, both parties remain in talks and we await further developments.

And since we're still on, here's SocGen on Pearson.

BE

Pearson shares are down 25% from their July peak despite FX tailwindsand reiterated targets. We think the current share price offers a compelling low-risk/high-reward profile. We upgrade our 2016e and 2017e EPS by 3% and 5%, respectively, which puts us 7% and 12% ahead of consensus, and we upgrade our rating to a Buy. Pearson becomes our preferred stock in the sector, replacing RELX after its strong run over the past three years.

BE

1/ High conviction by management We hosted a group investor meeting with CFO Coram Williams. The standout for us was his sustained high level of conviction (which we are told is shared by the rest of the executive team and the board) that the company's business analysis, surveys, deep dives and resulting targets are right. The CEO and CFO will more than triple their basic pay if they meet their On-Target goals, which broadly align with delivery of the £800m EBITA 2018e scenario.

BE

2/ Very low expectation that targets will be met All of Pearson’s targets out to 2018e are based on 31 December 2015 FX rates. We think this has been overlooked. We expect its January 2017 trading update to explicitly adjust these targets for prevailing rates, which currently means £780m of EBITA in 2017e (from £700m) and £880m in 2018e (from £800m). No recent consensus estimates (other than ours) have them meeting this 2017e target. We expect consensus upgrades, combined with a derisking of the valuation multiple.
3/ Pearson today: a lot of moving parts but clarity being added We think the equity story is well on the path to be successfully distilled down from 14 sub-divisions (each with their own structural stories) to two key debates: US college enrolment slippage (structural vs cyclical); and the mix effect of the other structural drivers. We maintain our view that the latter is a small net positive, while on the former, our model supports positive enrolment growth in 2017-18.
4/ Valuation suggests Pearson once again offers a compelling low-risk/high-reward profile It remains one of the sectors big debate stocks, as reflected by the considerable share price volatility over the past two years. Our valuation approach remains consistent, factoring in the structural headwinds, yet our TP of 1,030p (implies P/E ratios of 17.8x for 2016e and 14.5x for 2017e) implies 37% upside. Including the 52.0p DPS over the next 12 months (6.9% dividend yield), that supports a TSR of +44%.
